aicpa-topic.title: Digital Assets

body.p:
1.144 The advance of blockchain technology has facilitated the emergence of a new kind of asset — digital assets, assets in digitized form that are recorded and stored on a distributed ledger. Digital assets are a digital record made using cryptography for verification and security purposes on a digital decentralized ledger (referred to as a blockchain). A digital asset
Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA) Regulatory Notice 18-20 encourages firms to notify FINRA if they engage in activities related to digital assets. The full notice is available at www.finra.org/industry/notices/18-20.
is characterized by its ability to be used for a variety of purposes, including as a means of exchange, as a representation to provide or access goods or services, or as a financing vehicle, such as a security, among other uses.

1.145 Blockchain technology. Blockchain technology records a list of records, referred to as blocks, that are linked using cryptography. Each block contains a cryptographic hash of the previous block, a timestamp, and sequential transaction data.
1.146 Crypto asset. A type of digital asset, a crypto asset functions as a medium of exchange and has all of the following characteristics:

li.p: It is not issued by a jurisdictional authority (for example, a sovereign government).
It does not give rise to a contract between the holder and another party.
It is not considered a security under the Securities Act of 1933 or the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

body.p: These characteristics are not all-inclusive, and other facts and circumstances may need to be considered. Examples of crypto assets meeting these characteristics include bitcoin, bitcoin cash, and ether.

1.147 There are many different types of digital assets. One type is crypto assets, such as bitcoin, which constitute the first use-case of blockchain technology by decentralizing the transfer of value. The technology has continued to grow at a rapid pace to provide many more compelling enterprise, government, and retail use-cases. Digital assets are stored on a blockchain; however, digital asset wallets are the medium used to store private keys and their associated public keys or blockchain addresses, which provide the access rights to move digital assets across a blockchain. There are different types of wallets, which include software wallets (such as web or mobile wallets) and hardware wallets that can be used online (that is, a hot-storge wallet) or offline (that is, a cold storage wallet), depending on the desired security and liquidity.

1.148 The digital asset space is an evolving business environment, presenting practitioners with unique risks and complex challenges. The AICPA Digital Assets Working Group has developed a practice aid, which includes vital information on how to account for and audit digital assets.
This publication is available for download by AICPA and CIMA members at https://www.aicpa-cima.com/resources/download/accounting-for-and-auditing-of-digital-assets-practice-aid-pdf.

1.149 The rapid evolution of technologies underpinning digital assets and the continual introduction of new assets presents challenges for regulatory agencies and securities firms seeking to ensure compliance with existing laws concerning the custody and protection of customer securities.
See the FINRA website at https://www.finra.org/investors/investing/investment-products/digital-assets for additional information for investors.
Although the regulatory landscape remains fluid, the SEC issued Release No. 34-90788, Custody of Digital Asset Securities by Special Purpose Broker-Dealers, to establish an initial framework for broker-dealers to offer trading in digital assets via special purpose entities and satisfy their client possession and control obligations under SEC Rule 15c3-3.
